## MATHEMATICS

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 384, 390, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 418, 225, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 435, 880, 632]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 664, 215, 679]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 680, 732, 712]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 75.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 74, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
On a sketch of an Argand diagram, shade the region whose points represent complex numbers \(z\) satisfying the inequalities \(|z + 2 - 3\mathrm{i}|\leqslant 2\) and \(\arg z\leqslant \frac{3}{4}\pi .\) [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[316, 87, 710, 314]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 335, 920, 386]]<|/det|>
The variables \(x\) and \(y\) satisfy the equation \(x^{n}y^{2} = C\), where \(n\) and \(C\) are constants. The graph of \(\ln y\) against \(\ln x\) is a straight line passing through the points (0.31, 1.21) and (1.06, 0.91), as shown in the diagram.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 396, 680, 416]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(n\) and find the value of \(C\) correct to 2 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 397, 920, 415]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 437, 92]]<|/det|>
The parametric equations of a curve are

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[339, 100, 655, 121]]<|/det|>
\[x = 1 - \cos \theta ,\qquad y = \cos \theta - \frac{1}{4}\cos 2\theta .\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 128, 348, 159]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}} = -2 \sin^2\left(\frac{1}{2}\theta\right)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 154]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 74, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 608, 92]]<|/det|>
The angles \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\) lie between \(0^{\circ}\) and \(180^{\circ}\) and are such that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[346, 100, 650, 119]]<|/det|>
\[\tan (\alpha +\beta) = 2\quad \mathrm{and}\quad \tan \alpha = 3\tan \beta .\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 127, 401, 144]]<|/det|>
Find the possible values of \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 127, 920, 144]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
Find the complex numbers \(w\) which satisfy the equation \(w^{2} + 2\mathrm{i}w^{*} = 1\) and are such that \(\mathrm{Re} \, w \leqslant 0\). Give your answers in the form \(x + \mathrm{i}y\), where \(x\) and \(y\) are real.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 99, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
By sketching a suitable pair of graphs, show that the equation \(4 - x^{2} = \sec \frac{1}{2} x\) has exactly one root in the interval \(0 \leqslant x < \pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 420, 148, 437]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 419, 603, 437]]<|/det|>
Verify by calculation that this root lies between 1 and 2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 419, 920, 437]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 667, 141, 686]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 665, 920, 705]]<|/det|>
Use the iterative formula \(x_{n + 1} = \sqrt{4 - \sec\frac{1}{2}x_n}\) to determine the root correct to 2 decimal places. Give the result of each iteration to 4 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 686, 920, 704]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 787, 92]]<|/det|>
Find the quotient and remainder when \(8x^{3} + 4x^{2} + 2x + 7\) is divided by \(4x^{2} + 1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 665, 92]]<|/det|>
Show that the line through \(A\) and \(B\) does not intersect the line \(l\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 104, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[336, 87, 685, 280]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 303, 816, 323]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the curve \(y = \sin x \cos 2x\) for \(0 \leqslant x \leqslant \frac{1}{2}\pi\), and its maximum point \(M\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 335, 146, 354]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 335, 784, 354]]<|/det|>
Find the \(x\)-coordinate of \(M\), giving your answer correct to 3 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 335, 920, 354]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
Using the substitution \(u = \cos x\), find the area of the shaded region enclosed by the curve and the \(x\)-axis in the first quadrant, giving your answer in a simplified exact form.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]
